name: 2-fluoroquinoline-3-boronic acid
Reason: 2-fluoroquinoline-3-boronic acid has a melting point that can be predicted by considering its structural components. The basic unit for comparison is 2-fluorobenzene, which has a melting point of 10.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The fluorine atom introduces a significant dipole moment, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +10°C. The quinoline ring introduces additional rigidity and pi-stacking interactions, estimated at around +20°C. The boronic acid moiety introduces a hydroxyl group, which can participate in hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point by approximately +10°C. The presence of two additional phenyl groups linked in a linear fashion can augment the melting point due to increased molecular weight and van der Waals forces, estimated at around +20°C each.
